title: Georgia House - Day 16 (2026-02-09)
summary:
Here is a structured summary of the key points from the Georgia House session transcript:

**Overview**
The session featured a prayer by a Korean-American pastor, discussions of missionary work in Korea, and references to notable historical figures. The session appears to have focused on substantive legislative business, though specific bills were not mentioned in detail.

**Key Actions**
No specific bills were mentioned as being passed or referred.

**Bills Introduced (First Reading)**
No new bills were introduced.

**Notable Moments**
- Prayer delivered by Pastor Jung Hoon Sun of the Korean Community Presbyterian Church, who discussed the importance of political leaders keeping their promises and seeking God's wisdom.
- Pastor Sun highlighted the missionary work of William A. Linton and Horace Grant Underwood in Korea, as well as the sacrifices of U.S. soldiers in the Korean War.
- Pastor Sun encouraged the legislators to have the courage to lead their constituents in the right direction, even if it differs from public opinion, drawing parallels to figures like Moses and King David.

**Votes**
No recorded votes were mentioned.

**Attendance**
No specific quorum notes were provided.

**Adjournment**
The transcript does not indicate when the session was adjourned or when the next session would be.

you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you Mr. Clerk, will you please ring the bell. We're going to have the morning roll call vote. All members present will please vote green to signify their presence in the chamber and the clerk will unlock the machines. Have all members voted. Have all members voted. Yes, so the clerk will lock the machines. Doorkeepers, will you please close the doors and keep them closed. We will begin the day as is our custom with scripture reading and prayer by the chaplain, after which we will pledge allegiance to the flag of our country. Our chaplain this morning will be introduced by the lady from the 103rd House District representing Suhong. Thank you, Mr. Speaker and good morning, colleagues. I am delighted to introduce pastor Jung Hoon's son from the Korean community Presbyterian Church or KCPC in Gwinnit County. Many Korean immigrants like my family did find a sense of home community and resources at our churches when we first moved to America. KCPC is one of the oldest and the largest Korean American churches here in Georgia. They have over 2,000 members and they focus a lot on missionary work all over the world as well as a lot of the prison systems here in Georgia. Before pastor Sun started at KCPC in 2019, he started his own ministry in Seoul and grew it in San Diego as well as Hong Kong. His wife Rachel Ann is here if you can stand up. She is a professor at the Denver Theological Seminary as well and they have two sons who attend B for schools which is in the great district of 103. I'm excited to have pastor Sun as our chaplain this morning and I'm excited to hear from him. Pastor Sun. Good morning everyone. Thank you, Mr. Speaker, representative Su Hong, met Reeves and all the chamber members for inviting me to this special occasion. I'm so honored. I'm so honored to be here. As I was preparing my sermon, I asked AI, Artificial Intelligence Service. What do politicians and pastors have in common? The AI service replied, well, they always promise a better future and never deliver. What? At first I thought that was not fair, but I began to think about it more seriously. Am I a really a promise keeper as a pastor? How about yourself? Are you faithful? Are you faithful to the promise you made to God and people who sent you to this chamber? If you are having difficulty delivering the promise you have made, let me introduce you to the words of advice from the Bible. For Samuel 268 says, the Lord brings death and makes a life. The Lord sends poverty and wealth. He humbles and he exalts. He raises the poor from the dust and lifts the needy from the ash hip and prowls to six sevens as. But the Lord gives wisdom from his mouth comes knowledge and understanding. He holds success in store for the upright. He is shield to those whose walk is blameness. Bible clearly says that he is the provider and protector of his people. He is the source of every good thing we need, such as wisdom, courage, and wealth. He is also the shield of everything we cherish. Therefore, no matter how hard the issues we confront, we should never settle for a mediaco solution. Instead, we must pray hard, think hard, research hard, or even debate hard until we come up with this best solution for the wishes we need to tackle for the great state of Georgia. I know a wonderful man of God who was not satisfied with this mediaco solution and used God given inside to transform countless Korean lives. His missionary William A. Linton from Thomasville, Georgia. He graduated from Georgia Tech with top honors and left general metrics where his future was secure. He boarded a ship to an unknown country of Joseon, Joseon, presently Korea, to serve as a missionary. Representative Dallin Taylor, she is from Thomasville. Where are you by the way? Thank you for sending that great man to Korea 111 years ago. Let's see the picture of the family. Once he landed at Kunsan, a small town in South Korea in 1912, he taught Bible and English and he established many schools including Gurswony School and started modern education. But during the Japanese colonial period, he refused to bow down before Japanese got the Shinto shrine so he was expelled from the country by the Imperial Army. However, he returned to Korea after the liberation and founded this Hannam University that you are seeing right now, the picture, and when the Korean War was ended. In fact, one of our associate pastor Greggit from that university, Samoksan, would you wave your hand? It's one of the graduate of that Hannam University. Not only that, Linton's family is Third Sun, Hugh Linton, and his son Steve and John became missionaries too that helped to build colossus victims in Korea. Also, the fourth generation of the Linton family is still helping North Korean hospital and patients. Missionary Horace Grant Underwood and his descendants were another faceful man of God and we create deeply owe to him. Would you show a picture of this Horace missionary? Horace Grant Underwood, especially my wife here and I are the direct beneficiary of his ministry because we got the best Christian education from the university called Yonsei and which was founded by this missionary when he was 26 years old and in 1985. He and his four generations of children continued missionary

in Korea, building schools, hospitals, and churches, publishing Korean English dictionaries, and contributing significantly to the country's democratization. As we talk about the great man of God, we cannot pass by without mentioning the 50,000 U.S. officers and soldiers who lay down their lives during the Korean War. Without their dedication, South Korea would not have been able to attain the freedom and democracy that we enjoy these days. That's why we, our church ministers, to the Korean War veterans like this. There are now only 30, 30 Georgian veterans left, all of whom are well over 90 years. So we really appreciate their effort. Those are the people who have the wisdom and courage to live out the promises they made. They have made to God and the country to the people. I can't say that I fully understand the difficulties you face daily to accomplish the mission given to you. But I know for sure that what you are experiencing is not the first time in history, because history appeared itself. Most experienced racial, gender, and moral issues when he lay head to lead two million refugees out of Egypt to the promised land. King David also had to persuade those who had won great booties in a battlefield. So they fought this fight and collected these booties. And then these soldiers didn't want to share it with the other soldiers who were defending their families and their properties. A good leader, I believe, does not always follow the people to where they want to go. But instead, they tell and guide people where they must go. You not only represent the voters of your district, but I believe you are also supposed to lead them in the right direction. If Moses had followed the people's wishes, he would have returned to Egypt, because they complained. That way, we were better off when we were in Egypt in slave. But Moses didn't listen to them, because he had a clear vision of the promised land. If King David had followed the opinion of the soldiers who fought on the battlefield and wanted to keep all the booties themselves, the nation would be divided. But David did not. He said, no way, we're going to share all the booties with the people who are left behind. But still doing their job. That way, David were able to unite the kingdom together. To be a good leader, we need a godly wisdom to discern the truth and the courage to practice that truth. Dear fellow leaders in the chamber, if you seek wisdom from God, our provider, our protector, I firmly believe that he will surely give it to you. May God bless you and all the Georgians abundantly. Let us pray. Heavenly Father, we pray that you may grant wisdom and courage to these representatives who serve on behalf of the state of Georgia. Please give them the wisdom to discern the truth in this chaotic age, and the courage to practice what they promised before God and people. Help them all to be promised keepers. Also, I pray that you may help them. Device the best policy for all God's children. That's just for us. That's just for our generation or our region and our country. Help us to remember God's word, that says, when Colonel of Wheat falls to the ground and dies, he produces many seed. Help us all to lead. Our state by serving them diligently, we are Georgia, become one state under God, and the safest and strongest and most prosperous state in all of America. So we can be a great channel of blessing for others. We pray all these things in the precious name of our Jesus Christ, the Savior of the Lord, Amen, and amen. The door keepers will unlock the doors. Members, you may greet the chaplain in the south any room and we do appreciate that message here this morning at devotion. Very important. Thank you. Out the Agipson became the first African American to win a grand slam title, but long before making history, she was born in the segregated south and moved with her family up to New York, where she began to fall in love with tennis at a young age. After just a year of playing, she became a local star. And her talent would take her to this school in Tallahassee, Florida, and the University on a full athletic scholarship. She was successful in college, but as a professional, she struggled because she could not play in a lot of the segregated matches, but nonetheless, her talent would make room for her. And she would get her chance. In 1950, she became the first black woman to play in the US nationals. In 1958, she became the female of the year after winning the French Open, the Wimmelton and the US nationals being the first black tennis player to do so. She was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame, and what did she do after she retired from tennis, or she went on to break the color barrier, and the Ladies' Professional Golf Association. Out the Agipson is a strong and emblematic example of what happens when your preparation meets opportunity and you're given a chance.
